G.L. c. 212, \u00a7\u00a7 4 and 5.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, §§ 4 and 5, as the damages sought exceed $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County under G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the acts and omissions giving rise to this claim occurred within Middlesex County, and Defendant conducts business therein.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an owner or occupier of land owes lawful visitors a duty to maintain reasonably safe premises and to remedy or warn of hazards that the owner knows or should know of through reasonable care.  See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the landmark Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing a general duty of reasonable care to lawful entrants. Although the provided excerpt is only a concurring passage focused on trespassers, the case itself supports the proposition that owners/occupiers owe lawful visitors a duty to maintain reasonably safe premises and to remedy or warn of dangers they know or should know of. The concurrence implicitly accepts that broader duty while criticizing continued special treatment of trespassers.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: (From the majority opinion, not in the excerpt provided): "We hold that the common law distinctions between licensees and invitees are abolished. Henceforth, the occupier of land owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors."

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an owner or occupier of land owes lawful visitors a duty to maintain reasonably safe premises and to remedy or warn of hazards that the owner knows or should know of through reasonable care.  See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reaffirms that Massachusetts premises liability law imposes on property owners a general duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and to protect them from dangerous conditions the owner knows or should know about. Papadopoulos abolishes the natural/unnatural snow and ice distinction precisely in order to apply this existing Mounsey-based reasonable care standard to snow and ice hazards like any other hazard, which is exactly what the proposition describes.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt:
“We now discard the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, which had constituted an exception to the general rule of premises liability that a property owner owes a duty to all lawful visitors to use reasonable care to maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances. See Mounsey… at 708.”

“We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant had actual or constructive notice of the dangerous condition—namely, the spilled milk—yet failed to act within a reasonable time to remove or warn of it.  See Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973) (duty where condition existed for sufficient time to be discovered through reasonable care).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The case does address premises liability and the need to show that a dangerous condition existed long enough to be discovered by reasonable care, but its holding is that the evidence was *insufficient* to establish that time element. The court reverses a plaintiff’s verdict and orders judgment for the defendant, emphasizing that the circumstantial evidence did not warrant an inference that the condition had existed for a sufficient time. Thus, Oliveri is authority limiting, not affirming, liability on these facts, and does not support the proposition that the defendant here had constructive notice of spilled milk and failed to act in reasonable time.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it. … There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required. The mere stickiness or adherence of the substance to the step is not such a quality as, in common knowledge, established the time element. … Exceptions sustained. Judgment for the defendant.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty constitutes negligence under G.L. c. 231, § 85, which imposes liability for damages proximately resulting from negligent acts or omissions.

Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.raw_text: Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Mass. 273 (1911)
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.proposition: Comparable Massachusetts precedent establishes a store’s liability when a customer is injured due to unremedied floor hazards.  See Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Mass. 273 (1911) (liability where hazard existed long enough for reasonable inspection); Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263 (1961) (failure of grocery store to maintain safe aisle conditions); Simmons v. W. F. Wood, Inc., 390 Mass. 857 (1984); Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988).
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.case_name: Anjou v. Boston Elevated Railway Co.
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.support_reasoning: The case holds a carrier liable where a passenger slipped on a foreign substance (a banana peel) that had been on the floor long enough that employees, exercising reasonable care, should have discovered and removed it. Although the setting is a railway platform rather than a retail store, the opinion clearly articulates the same principle invoked in the proposition: liability arises when a hazard on the floor exists for a sufficient time that reasonable inspection and maintenance would have remedied it.
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The inference might have been drawn from the appearance and condition of the banana peel that it had been upon the platform a considerable period of time, in such position that it would have been seen and removed by the employees of the defendant if they had performed their duty… The obligation rested upon the defendant to keep its station reasonably safe for its passengers. It might have been found that the platform was suffered to remain in such condition as to be a menace to those rightfully walking upon it.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: Comparable Massachusetts precedent establishes a store’s liability when a customer is injured due to unremedied floor hazards.  See Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Mass. 273 (1911) (liability where hazard existed long enough for reasonable inspection); Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263 (1961) (failure of grocery store to maintain safe aisle conditions); Simmons v. W. F. Wood, Inc., 390 Mass. 857 (1984); Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988).
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: This case actually reverses a jury verdict for the injured customer and holds that the store is not liable because there was insufficient evidence that the hazard existed long enough or was sufficiently observable to charge the store with notice. While the opinion recites the general duty to keep premises reasonably safe, its holding is that the plaintiff failed to prove negligence under those standards. Thus, it does not serve as precedent ‘establishing a store’s liability’ for unremedied floor hazards; it illustrates when liability is not established.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant’s motion should have been allowed. ‘The defendant owed to customers a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for their use. He, however, is not an insurer of safety. Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action.’ … On the evidence here we think that the negligence of the defendant is left to conjecture.”

Simmons v. W. F. Wood, Inc., 390 Mass. 8.raw_text: Simmons v. W. F. Wood, Inc., 390 Mass. 857 (1984)
Simmons v. W. F. Wood, Inc., 390 Mass. 8.proposition: Comparable Massachusetts precedent establishes a store’s liability when a customer is injured due to unremedied floor hazards.  See Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Mass. 273 (1911) (liability where hazard existed long enough for reasonable inspection); Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263 (1961) (failure of grocery store to maintain safe aisle conditions); Simmons v. W. F. Wood, Inc., 390 Mass. 857 (1984); Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988).
Simmons v. W. F. Wood, Inc., 390 Mass. 8.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns criminal speedy-trial rights under Massachusetts Rule of Criminal Procedure 36 and related appellate-procedure timing issues. It does not involve premises liability, store owners, customer injuries, or floor hazards, nor does it discuss duties of businesses to maintain safe conditions. Citing Simmons v. W. F. Wood, Inc. for store liability based on unremedied floor hazards is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the text of the opinion.
Simmons v. W. F. Wood, Inc., 390 Mass. 8.relevant_excerpt:
The defendants challenge the denial of their motions to dismiss indictments against them because of the Commonwealth’s failure to afford them a speedy retrial after reversal of their original convictions. We affirm.

…

We hold that, for purposes of rule 36 (b) (1) (D), a reversal requiring a new trial is not final before issuance of the rescript by the appellate court.

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.proposition: Comparable Massachusetts precedent establishes a store’s liability when a customer is injured due to unremedied floor hazards.  See Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Mass. 273 (1911) (liability where hazard existed long enough for reasonable inspection); Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263 (1961) (failure of grocery store to maintain safe aisle conditions); Simmons v. W. F. Wood, Inc., 390 Mass. 857 (1984); Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988).
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.support_reasoning: This case concerns a wrongful death arising from use of a freight elevator, not a customer slip-and-fall or other injury from a floor hazard in a retail store. The SJC analyzes a landowner’s duty to maintain an elevator and concludes there was no negligence because the risk was obvious and the specific misuse was not reasonably foreseeable. It does not establish liability for unremedied floor hazards; if anything, it limits premises liability in a distinct elevator-context scenario, so it does not support the cited proposition about store floor conditions.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….’ … The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred. We are satisfied that, on the evidence, no such conclusion was warranted.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Massachusetts courts further recognize that the foreseeability of harm from spilled liquids in retail stores imposes a duty of periodic inspection and prompt cleanup.  See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007).
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The case does recognize that self‑service grocery operations make spills (including produce and liquids) reasonably foreseeable and that stores must take reasonable precautions (such as monitoring and cleanup) commensurate with those risks. However, Sheehan adopts a general “mode of operation” rule about foreseeability and substitutes it for traditional notice; it does not specifically articulate a Massachusetts duty of periodic inspection and prompt cleanup as such, nor frame the duty in those terms. The proposition overstates and mischaracterizes the holding by converting a general foreseeability-based duty into a specific requirement of periodic inspections and prompt cleanup of spilled liquids.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “In particular, as is the case here, fruit and vegetable debris presents an obvious risk of injury to a customer, and a reasonably prudent person would not place these items in an aisle or allow them to remain there. Thus, because the determination of reasonableness is a question of fact, the trier of fact must determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee or anticipate that a foreseeable risk stemming from the owner’s mode of operation could occur and whether the owner exercised reasonable care in maintaining the premise in a safe condition commensurate with these foreseeable risks.”

Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248 (1957.proposition: By failing to institute or follow reasonable inspection and cleanup procedures, Defendant directly violated its duty under the standards of ordinary care articulated in Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248 (1957) and Coates v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 450 Mass. 490 (2008).
Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248 (1957.support_reasoning: Thurlow v. Crossman is a trespass case about whether a law enforcement officer’s entry and presence on private property was lawful under statutory authority and common-law principles, not a premises-liability or negligence case about inspections or cleanup procedures. The opinion contains no discussion of a defendant’s duty to institute or follow reasonable inspection and cleanup protocols, nor any articulation of an ordinary-care standard in that context. Citing Thurlow for a proposition about inspection/cleanup duties misstates its holding and reasoning.
Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248 (1957.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant in his capacity as enforcement officer was authorized, in the performance of his duties, to ‘enter upon and pass through or over private property or lands whether or not covered by water.’ … It appears from the findings of the auditor that the defendant entered the premises to investigate suspected illegal activities … His original entry being lawful there was nothing in his subsequent conduct which served to make him a trespasser ab initio.”

Coates v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 450 M.raw_text: Coates v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 450 Mass. 490 (2008)
Coates v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 450 M.proposition: By failing to institute or follow reasonable inspection and cleanup procedures, Defendant directly violated its duty under the standards of ordinary care articulated in Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248 (1957) and Coates v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 450 Mass. 490 (2008).
Coates v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 450 M.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the scope of a Massachusetts District Court judge’s authority under Mass. R. Crim. P. 29 to revise or revoke a sentence and whether he could vacate a guilty finding and substitute a continuance without a finding. It does not address premises liability, inspection or cleanup procedures, or any duty of ordinary care under Thurlow v. Crossman, nor does it articulate or apply standards of ordinary care in a negligence context. The proposition attributed to Coates relates to tort duties that are not discussed anywhere in this criminal-procedure decision.
Coates v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 450 M.relevant_excerpt: “By the explicit terms of rule 29, if a judge determines that justice has not been done, the judge may revise or revoke a sentence, not a finding of guilt. When the judge vacated the finding of guilt on the criminal complaint and entered a continuance without a finding subject to the payment of restitution, he effectively erased all vestiges of the criminal proceedings against the defendant. Such action was not within the purview of the judge’s authority under rule 29.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: C. Award interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
